summary: This is a letter from the law firm Smith Villazor LLP to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The firm, representing the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, informs the court that they have been notified of a subpoena directed at the program and requests a briefing schedule to file a motion to quash it. The letter includes procedural deadlines set by the court.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Maxwell case to whom the letter is addressed, setting procedural deadlines.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney from Smith Villazor LLP who signs the letter and is authorized to accept service of the subpoena on behalf of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program administrator.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Mark Stewart Cohen
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual against whom the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was established to resolve claims of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (United States v. Maxwell) from which this subpoena arises.

connections.description: Patrick J. Smith's firm represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.
The document references the Maxwell criminal case and the program for claims against Epstein, implying their legal and alleged operational connection.
Smith is formally communicating with and making requests of Judge Nathan regarding court procedure.

events.title: Letter to Court Regarding Subpoena
events.description: Smith Villazor LLP informs Judge Nathan that they have learned of a subpoena directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and requests a schedule to file a motion to quash.

events.title: Government's Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The government's motion to quash the subpoena is due.

events.title: Program's Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The deadline for the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program to file its motion to quash the subpoena.

events.title: Defense Response Deadline
events.description: The deadline for Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team to respond to the motions to quash.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, represented by Smith Villazor LLP, is the target of a subpoena in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case.
The program was established to confidentially resolve claims of sexual abuse against Jeffrey Epstein, his estate, and related parties.
Both the government and the program's administrator intend to file motions to quash the subpoena.
Judge Alison J. Nathan set a tight briefing schedule for motions related to the subpoena, noting the impending start date of Maxwell's trial.
The document reveals legal efforts by Maxwell's defense to obtain documents from the victim compensation program, potentially for trial preparation.
